title: Understanding Isoelectronic Species
text: Isoelectronic species have the same number of electrons. To determine if ions are isoelectronic with Kr, first find the number of electrons in a neutral Kr atom.

title: Electron Count of Krypton
text: Krypton (Kr) is a noble gas with an atomic number of $$36$$. This means a neutral Kr atom has $$36$$ electrons.

title: Determine Electron Count for Each Ion
text: Calculate the number of electrons for each ion: A. K**+, B. Sr**2+, C. Br**-, D. Se**2+. Remember to adjust the electron count based on the charge of the ion.

title: Adjusting Electron Count for Ions
text: For a positive ion (cation), subtract the charge from the atomic number to find the electron count. For a negative ion (anion), add the charge to the atomic number.

title: Calculate Electrons for K**+
text: Potassium (K) has an atomic number of $$19$$. As K**+ is a cation, subtract $$1$$ from $$19$$ to find the electron count.

title: Calculate Electrons for Sr**2+
text: Strontium (Sr) has an atomic number of $$38$$. As Sr**2+ is a cation, subtract $$2$$ from $$38$$ to find the electron count.

title: Calculate Electrons for Br**-
text: Bromine (Br) has an atomic number of $$35$$. As Br**- is an anion, add $$1$$ to $$35$$ to find the electron count.

title: Calculate the Charge for Se**2-
text: Selenium (Se) has an atomic number of $$34$$. As Se**2+ is an ion, subtract $$2$$ from $$34$$ to find the electron count.

title: Identify Isoelectronic Ions
text: Compare the electron counts of the ions with the electron count of Kr (36 electrons). Select the ions that have the same number of electrons as Kr.
